solution: Clearly one color isn't enough; $\boxed{2}$ colors will work because the tessellation shown is topologically identical to a chessboard (that is, imagine straightening out the diagonal lines to form an array of squares. This process doesn't change which tiles share a side.).
gpt_response:
ChatCompletion(id='chatcmpl-9A2dsZlr7SR60TfBVJB34o8FanqZY', choices=[Choice(finish_reason='stop', index=0, logprobs=None, message=ChatCompletionMessage(content='The least number of colors needed to shade the tessellation shown is 3. 

We can see that the tessellation is composed of triangle shapes that are repeated throughout. To color the tiles in such a way that no two tiles sharing a side are the same color, we can work in sections. Each section of the tessellation can be colored using 3 different colors, making sure that adjacent tiles are not the same color.

Therefore, the minimum number of colors needed to shade the tessellation is 3.', role='assistant', function_call=None, tool_calls=None))], created=1712180464, model='gpt-3.5-turbo-0125', object='chat.completion', system_fingerprint='fp_b28b39ffa8', usage=CompletionUsage(completion_tokens=103, prompt_tokens=177, total_tokens=280))
